newsitem.title: USA: Fed begins meeting, no rate hike expected.
newsitem.headline: Fed begins meeting, no rate hike expected.

text.p: The Federal Reserve began a two-day policy-making meeting Tuesday amid widespread expectations it will decide to hold interest rates steady.
With inflation tame and, by at least by one measure, at a 30-year low, the U.S. central bank has scant justification for raising short-term rates now, economists said.
"They won't do anything," said Cynthia Latta, of Massachusetts-based economic consultants DRI/McGraw Hill. "There are no signs out there of overheating."

But she and many other analysts expect the central bank to raise rates eventually to counter an anticipated buildup in inflationary pressures stemming from a tight labour market and stepped-up wage demands by workers.

The central bank's policy-making Federal Open Market Committee began its two-day meeting as scheduled at 2:30 p.m. (1930 GMT) on Tuesday. It was not expected to announce its rate decision until around 2:15 p.m. (1915 GMT) on Wednesday.

The meeting comes after news last week that the economy grew at a surprisingly robust annualized pace of 4.7 percent in the final three months of last year. But inflation remained low, with the so-called implicit price deflator rising at a 1.4 percent rate in the quarter, the slowest pace since 1967.
Two economic reports released Tuesday painted a picture of an economy that looks to have further room to run, but perhaps not at the rapid pace seen at the tail end of 1996.

The Conference Board, a New York business research group, said its index of leading indicators -- designed to predict economic conditions six to nine months ahead -- edged up 0.1 percent in December after a revised 0.2 percent November rise.
The Commerce Department said that new home sales eased by 1 percent in December, although sales for 1996 as a whole were their strongest in 18 years.
The Fed has held rates steady for over a year, since cutting them by a quarter percentage point on Jan. 31, 1996.
The federal funds rate that commercial banks charge each other for loans now stands at 5.25 percent. The discount rate the Fed charges on its loans to the banks is 5 percent.
Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan told state governors Sunday he saw no evidence of significant price pressures in the economy, Iowa Gov. Terry Branstad said.
"He gave a positive report. We've had growth with low inflation," Branstad told reporters after the governors' closed-door meeting with the Fed chief.

Two pet economic indicators of Greenspan's -- the employment cost index, which measures workers' wages and benefits, and the National Association of Purchasing Managers survey -- have shown little sign of inflationary pressures.
In public testimony to Congress last month, Greenspan painted a picture of an economy that was surprisingly free of inflationary pressures six years into expansion.
He also warned of the risk that inflation could pick up as workers take advantage of the tight labour market to demand much higher wages and benefits from their employers.
He made clear that the Fed would not wait to act until inflation picked up, but would raise rates if it had persuasive evidence that inflationary pressures were building.
That is why many analysts believe a rate increase is likely, perhaps as soon as the Fed's next policy-making meeting March 25.
